newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - GDP forecasts ignore labour mkt reform - Howard.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - GDP forecasts ignore labour mkt reform - Howard.

text.p: Australian Prime Minister John howard said budget growth forecasts were based on existing rigidities in the economy, including the labour market.

""Well, those levels of growth of course are predicated on the existing regidities in the economy, for example a regulated labour market," Howard said in a television interview, responding to a question suggesting the budget growth forecasts would not lead to significant drops in unemployment.
"If we can get our industrial relations reforms through the Senate, then I believe that will start over time to make a contribution," Howard said.
After growing at 4.1 percent in each of the last two years, the government forecast the economy to grow at 3.5 percent over 1996/97 (July/June) in its budget released on Tuesday.
The unemployment rate is only expected to fall to 8.25 percent from the 8.5 percent at the end of 1995/96.
Earlier in the interview Howard declined to nominate an unemployment rate target for the end of his government's term.
His Liberal-National coalition government does not have a majority in the Senate, Australian's upper house, and need minority party votes to get the labour market reforms into law.
